Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery phiale mesomphalos; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; two concentric added white bands above part of lotus flower in white outline with alternating added red and white petals; exterior: trace of undetermined rim pattern above two bands; below, painted decoration consisting of part of back of an animal, possibly a lion, to right; painted inscription in field.
Curator's comments: The number '42' is written in pencil on the interior surface of the sherd. The absence of any filling ornament suggests that the phiale belongs to the Chalice Style. for parallels, see Berlin V.I. 3150, 3. Lemos incorrectly identified the sherd as Oxford 1888.218 and identified the image on the sherd as the hindquarters of an animal. She does refer to the correct inscription in her catalogue and does refer toCook and Woodhead's correct catalogue entry as well.
Bibliographic references: Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 169, no. 201)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 732, no. 921)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 298, no. 995) (Incorrectly labelled as Oxford 1888.218, V186n, 862)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1951) (phase 2)
